pageProps.contentHtml:
Hahn-Banach, operator theory

Let V\mathcal{V}V be the subspace of L∞([0,1],μ)L^\infty\p{\br{0, 1}, \mu}L∞([0,1],μ) (where μ\muμ is the Lebesgue measure on [0,1]\br{0, 1}[0,1]) defined by

V={f∈L∞([0,1],μ) | lim⁡n→∞n∫[0,1/n]f dμ exists}.\mathcal{V} = \set{f \in L^\infty\p{\br{0, 1}, \mu} \st \lim_{n\to\infty} n\int_{\br{0,1/n}} f \,\diff\mu \text{ exists}}.V={f∈L∞([0,1],μ)∣∣​n→∞lim​n∫[0,1/n]​fdμ exists}.
  1. Prove that there exists φ∈(L∞([0,1]))∗\phi \in \p{L^\infty\p{\br{0, 1}}}^*φ∈(L∞([0,1]))∗ such that φ(f)=lim⁡n→∞n∫[0,1/n]f dμ\phi\p{f} = \lim_{n\to\infty} n \int_{\br{0,1/n}} f \,\diff\muφ(f)=limn→∞​n∫[0,1/n]​fdμ for every f∈Vf \in \mathcal{V}f∈V.
  2. Show that, given any φ∈(L∞([0,1]))∗\phi \in \p{L^\infty\p{\br{0, 1}}}^*φ∈(L∞([0,1]))∗ satisfying the condition in (a) above, there exists no g∈L1([0,1])g \in L^1\p{\br{0,1}}g∈L1([0,1]) such that φ(f)=∫fg dμ\phi\p{f} = \int fg \,\diff\muφ(f)=∫fgdμ for all f∈L∞([0,1])f \in L^\infty\p{\br{0, 1}}f∈L∞([0,1]).
Solution.

  1. Let φ ⁣:V→R\func{\phi}{\mathcal{V}}{\R}φ:V→R be given by

    φ(f)=lim⁡n→∞n∫[0,1/n]f dμ,\phi\p{f} = \lim_{n\to\infty} n \int_{\br{0,1/n}} f \,\diff\mu,φ(f)=n→∞lim​n∫[0,1/n]​fdμ,

    which is well-defined by definition of V\mathcal{V}V. It's clear that this is linear, and because

    ∣n∫[0,1/n]f dμ∣≤∥f∥L∞,\abs{n \int_{\br{0,1/n}} f \,\diff\mu} \leq \norm{f}_{L^\infty},∣∣​n∫[0,1/n]​fdμ∣∣​≤∥f∥L∞​,

    we see that ∥φ∥≤1\norm{\phi} \leq 1∥φ∥≤1, so φ∈V∗\phi \in \mathcal{V}^*φ∈V∗. Thus, by Hahn-Banach, φ\phiφ extends to a function in (L∞([0,1]))∗\p{L^\infty\p{\br{0,1}}}^*(L∞([0,1]))∗, which was what we wanted to show.

  2. Suppose otherwise, and let g∈L1([0,1])g \in L^1\p{\br{0,1}}g∈L1([0,1]) represent φ\phiφ. Notice that if f=χ[a,b]f = \chi_{\br{a,b}}f=χ[a,b]​ with a>0a > 0a>0, then f∈L∞([0,1])f \in L^\infty\p{\br{0,1}}f∈L∞([0,1]) and φ(f)=0\phi\p{f} = 0φ(f)=0. Thus, if x∈(0,1]x \in \poc{0, 1}x∈(0,1] is a Lebesgue point of ggg, then for 0<r<x0 < r < x0<r<x, we have

    0=φ(χ[x−r,x+r])2r=12r∫[x−r,x+r]g dμ→r→0g(x).0 = \frac{\phi\p{\chi_{\br{x-r,x+r}}}}{2r} = \frac{1}{2r} \int_{\br{x - r, x + r}} g \,\diff\mu \xrightarrow{r\to0} g\p{x}.0=2rφ(χ[x−r,x+r]​)​=2r1​∫[x−r,x+r]​gdμr→0​g(x).

    Thus, g=0g = 0g=0 a.e., but this is impossible since, for example,

    1=φ(1)=∫g dμ=0.1 = \phi\p{1} = \int g \,\diff\mu = 0.1=φ(1)=∫gdμ=0.
